name: Vulturine Guineafowl
description: It has black-blue coloration with white dots and stripes. It earned its name from its bare head and neck, offset by a rich mantle of drooping feathers.
spread_note: Eastern Africa - southern Ethiopia, Somalia, Kenya, northern Tanzania
image_alt: Vulturine Guineafowl, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 45–58 cm; tail length 15 cm; wing length 28–31 cm; weight 1.4–1.8 kg
reproduction: Females lay 8–15 eggs, incubated for 23–27 days.
attractions: It inhabits savannas, where several guineafowl always form groups of varying sizes. One member keeps watch while others dig for food with strong claws and beaks. During breeding, they form pairs that jointly feed and lead the young, though only the female incubates. They spend most of the day on the ground foraging, and like all guineafowl, prefer running over flying, even when threatened. They only fly into trees or large bushes at night.
breeding: The first two guineafowl arrived at the zoo in 1955, but records of their fate are missing. In modern times, we’ve kept them since 2005.
